scripts.comment: A couple examples using the block are shown below!

The Caesar cipher is a type of substitution cipher in which each letter of the alphabet is shifted by a fixed number of positions. In this example, we will shift the values on the ASCII table rather than the alphabet so we can represent a larger set of characters. Edit the custom block on the left to view the problem!

The scripts below use the block as part of an encrypted texting app! First, duplicate this role (under the "Room" tab) and invite yourself (in a new browser window) or a friend to the role. Then run the first script to send encrypted messages! Don't forget to use the same key for each role!
Could you add encryption to another communication app (such as a chat server)? If you don't know the key, how might you try to break the cipher?

A couple examples using the block are shown below!

The Caesar cipher is a type of substitution cipher in which each letter of the alphabet is shifted by a fixed number of positions.
Edit the custom block on the left to view the problem!

The Caesar cipher is a type of substitution cipher in which each letter of the alphabet is shifted by a fixed number of positions. In this example, we will shift the values on the ASCII table rather than the alphabet so we can represent a larger set of characters.

<script><custom-block collabId="item_170" s="shift %txt by %n"><block collabId="item_170_1" s="getLastAnswer"></block><block collabId="item_170_2" var="key"/></custom-block></script>
<comment collabId="item_180" x="355.3333333333333" y="185.2222222222222" w="90" collapsed="false">add comment here...</comment>

The scripts below use the block as part of an encrypted texting app! First, duplicate this role (under the "Room" tab) and then run the first block to send encrypted messages! If both roles are using the same key, they should be able to communicate!

The scripts below use the block as part of an encrypted texting app! First, duplicate this role (under the "Room" tab) and invite yourself (in a new browser window) or a friend to the role. Then run the first script to send encrypted messages!
Don't forget to use the same key for each role!
